content.raw:
In an ideal situation proper unit tests should be able to say if the open action is working although the close action is broken. I understand that we are not able to do that, in that case:

 * Test for open the gripper (as it is now)
 * Test for close the gripper (same code as open, with only an ASSERT_TRUE at the end of the open action to be sure it's open and all the EXPECT or ASSERT for the close action after it.

Does it makes sense?
content.html:
In an ideal situation proper unit tests should be able to say if the open action is working although the close action is broken. I understand that we are not able to do that, in that case:

  • Test for open the gripper (as it is now)
  • Test for close the gripper (same code as open, with only an ASSERT_TRUE at the end of the open action to be sure it's open and all the EXPECT or ASSERT for the close action after it.

Does it makes sense?

content.raw:
Not be so sure, since you are in fact, right. And my initial sentence was plain wrong, since gtest [does not offer a timeout functionality](https://code.google.com/p/googletest/issues/detail?id=348). It is CTest which implements this for our testsuite.

Even with this, I'm not sure than we want to keep them into our unit tests. Use cases I can see:

 * Developing and running standalone test: if it stucks, the developer is just looking. CTRL+C. You know its not working.
 * Running test suite: it should be run from make test command, with implements proper timeout. 

Maybe I'm missing other useful cases. Open for discussion to me.
content.html:
Not be so sure, since you are in fact, right. And my initial sentence was plain wrong, since gtest does not offer a timeout functionality. It is CTest which implements this for our testsuite.

Even with this, I'm not sure than we want to keep them into our unit tests. Use cases I can see:

  • Developing and running standalone test: if it stucks, the developer is just looking. CTRL+C. You know its not working.
  • Running test suite: it should be run from make test command, with implements proper timeout.

Maybe I'm missing other useful cases. Open for discussion to me.

content.raw: I'm sure I'm wrong, but I think the gtest timeout will not work if you run the test executable as a standalone binary.
content.html: I'm sure I'm wrong, but I think the gtest timeout will not work if you run the test executable as a standalone binary.

content.raw: I would go for indepent tests here, so one for closing the grasp, starting from an open position. One for open the grasp, starting by a close position. unit tests should be ideally totally independent.
content.html: I would go for indepent tests here, so one for closing the grasp, starting from an open position. One for open the grasp, starting by a close position. unit tests should be ideally totally independent.

content.raw:
Is this 100 timeout depending on machine performance? If so, my personal opinion is that we should stop coding timeouts in this manner and rely on gtest own timeout for killing tests in case of they get stuck.

If we want to control the time used by an action (here the grasp time) is not changing (mostly increase) in an unreasonable manner, let's transform this into a performance test.
content.html:
Is this 100 timeout depending on machine performance? If so, my personal opinion is that we should stop coding timeouts in this manner and rely on gtest own timeout for killing tests in case of they get stuck.

If we want to control the time used by an action (here the grasp time) is not changing (mostly increase) in an unreasonable manner, let's transform this into a performance test.

content.raw:
This std::map version makes the assumption that if the passed in `CollisionPtr`s  are not null then they are valid collisions. Otherwise, it uses the same strategy as the std::vector version to look-up collision by name later in `NewContact`.  

I did this because it was kind of strange to let users pass in `CollisionPtr`s but then they are not used. If I were the user I would expect this function call to be more efficient then calling the std::vector one given that more information are available. It's a nice convenient method though.
content.html:
This std::map version makes the assumption that if the passed in CollisionPtrs are not null then they are valid collisions. Otherwise, it uses the same strategy as the std::vector version to look-up collision by name later in NewContact.

I did this because it was kind of strange to let users pass in CollisionPtrs but then they are not used. If I were the user I would expect this function call to be more efficient then calling the std::vector one given that more information are available. It's a nice convenient method though.

content.raw: With this change the std::map version of CreateFilter assumes that the passed in map has correct collision names while the std::vector version ofCreateFilter does not make that assumption.
content.html: With this change the std::map version of CreateFilter assumes that the passed in map has correct collision names while the std::vector version ofCreateFilter does not make that assumption.

content.raw:
`CreateFilter` function in the above line performs an additional step to find CollisionPtrs based on the vector of names passed in, but in this case it's already available from this function's `_collisions` argument. 

So I did a little refactoring to avoid looking up CollisionPtrs again, see [fix_gripper_filter](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/fix_gripper_filter..fix_gripper#diff) branch. Moved code for initiating `ContactPublishers` here in this function
content.html:
CreateFilter function in the above line performs an additional step to find CollisionPtrs based on the vector of names passed in, but in this case it's already available from this function's _collisions argument.

So I did a little refactoring to avoid looking up CollisionPtrs again, see fix_gripper_filter branch. Moved code for initiating ContactPublishers here in this function
